In the world of Claymore, humans are hunted by creatures called “Yoma”, which possess the bodies of humans and use them to infiltrate society. some times they will shed their human shells and become monsters that no mortal man can stand up against. To combat this an organization is created which employs specialized warriors known as “Claymores”; young, beautiful women who have been imbued with the blood of the Yoma.
Story: 7/10
One of the things I enjoyed most about Claymore’s story is how it utilized women. Unlike most anime (and most forms of entertainment in general), the women in Claymore are not presented in a sexualmanner. While attractive, they maintain an almost sexless air about them, and at least on the surface, they seem not to be preoccupied with romance or the pleasures of the flesh. No skimpy outfits, no watermelon tits, no naked bathing scenes. The Claymores are just badasses who kill things, and do so without constantly reminding you that they are women. In stark contrast, the men in Claymore are all virtually helpless. I feel that this is a nice and much needed role reversal for anime.


Art & Animation: 8/10

On the technical side of things, Claymore is equally impressive. As a Madhouse production, you are pretty much guaranteed top notch animation. The show remains consistently smooth throughout its run, with perhaps a bit of emphasis placed on the fight scenes. What really sells the presentation, however, is the art style. The shading, lighting, and use of color work well in making Claymore as fittingly dark and dreary as possible. Being based on a beautiful graphic novel-quality manga, Claymore had big shoes to fill in terms of its visuals, and it completely achieves success here by capturing the look of the manga perfectly.


Sound: 7/10

Another thing that carries Claymore along is its great music, a mix of haunting instrumental pieces and visceral metal. Some of the themes here are very memorable, particularly the incredible ending song, Danzai no Hana ~Guilty Sky~, a symphonic rock hybrid with beautiful lyrics.


Character: 8/10

Claymore is great low-fantasy at its finest. The bulk of the show consists of Clare traveling from one Yoma battle to the next, but there are some great introspective explorations of the characters, most notably Clare. When we begin, Clare is frigid and emotionless. But through her interactions with Raki and her encounters with other Claymores and Yoma, specifically the transcendent Yoma known as “Awakened Beings” and her increasing knowledge of the relationship between all of these elements, Clare begins to change rather dynamically.


Enjoyment: 8/10

However, as nice as the story is, Claymore is foremost an action show. The fight scenes are the core of the show, and if you are not a big fan of action, gore and the staple “technique-talk” of shonen anime, there is a good chance that Claymore will not tickle your fancy. But if you do appreciate amazing fight scenes when you see them, Claymore will be absolute bliss. You will be hard pressed to find a show more violent and brutal. Even Berserk does not compare. Hell, even Hokuto no Ken does not quite elicit the same cringes that Claymore gave me. As much as I am a fan of character development and great narrative, I would be lying if I said the fight scenes in Claymore did not fill me with boyish glee.


Overall: 8/10

Claymore is a great show, but it is not for everyone. If you are into more poignant stuff and are not enamored by fight scenes, you may want to pass up Claymore and watch Berserk instead. But if you love action and brutality, Claymore just might be your ticket to a great time. In all, it is one of the best all-out action/fantasy shows I have seen in a long time.

As this review of Claymore is coming over a decade after its actual release, I tried to level-off my expectations.
Basically, the anime is about world infested with yoma, or demons that eat people. What's tricky is that these creatures are able to disguise themselves by taking the memories of a person they had consumed, and adapting into society. Given the great peril, an organization produced what is known as "Claymore" - individuals who have decided have themselves fused with yoma, in order to exterminate the evil beings. 
The narrative follows the life of Clare, one who has decided to give up her humanity to getthe power to kill yoma. She saves a Raki, a normal boy, who decides to journey with her. 


We've heard similar storylines before from the likes of Saiyuki, Blood +, heck, even X-Men (shows at the top of mind that came before 2007): those same people who have the "evil"  are the ones who are protecting the "normal humans." Through this, the the usual bittersweet conflict within the audience occurs: we understand that citizens are afraid of the fighters, and at the same time we feel ever-so-deeply for those so-called "demonic beings," who are sacrificing their lives for the very people who hate them. What's more is that the Claymore used to be human, and have very humane reasons for fighting. 


Because of the overly familiar plot, the series started quite slowly. The art was also unusual, seemed disproportionate, and distracting (it proved difficult to differentiate the characters, especially Claymore, who have similar features). There were a few mediocre twists after another, but eventually, the story began to pick up the pace. 


One great positive thing I would like to point out is that the directors were not afraid to jump into the bizarre or dive into the disturbing - through the characters' unique personalities or through battle techniques or damage incurred (labeled that way, so as not to spoil anything). This definitely increased appeal. Another strongpoint of the anime is that it broke usual boundaries between characters and this can shake the audience. Many ideas and events that took place were unique and added to viewers' enjoyment.


There were a few things in the execution of the series that were insufferable such as, but not limited to, the excessive flashbacks (especially when it came to Raki), the repetitive dialogues, and several recapitulations of certain themes. Perhaps the makers should give more credit to the audience. Once a scene of a character showing the key experiences or reason for fighting is shown, we would be able to infer what the character is feeling or would desire, instead of shoving it up our faces over and over again. 


What was also not appreciated was that though Clare kept getting "stronger," she was not as effective in battle. Then all of a sudden, her willpower makes everything okay. Especially at the final arc, the coherence of the story was lost because of this. All logic got even more muddled when Clare was deterred to fulfill what she had set out to do for no substantial reason. It leaves the audiences with a feeling of confusion and disarray - not with the sense of intrigue and excitement, but because of poor explanation and plot flow. 


In conclusion, Claymore did not disappoint in terms of excitement, action, and entertainment. I definitely would have rated the anime higher if it were not for the ending.

So basically everyone and their grandmother has seen Claymore. I think I was one of the few people who didn't know about Claymore when it first came out but I also chose not to watch it until it was completed, either way I'm usually pretty behind on the curve when it comes to the latest and greatest anime for this very reason....I hate being held in suspense for weeks while they come out with new episodes. Especially if it's an anime with a lot of fillers because then you are held in suspense indefinitely. Luckily Claymore is not that type of show. It's 26 episodesof pure action, pure gore and no fillers....prepare for a wild ride!


~art

This is a relatively new show [2007] but the animation isn't really dazzling. I couldn't detect any CGI which is a shame [Don't get me wrong I really hate CGI when it's used for visual art, but it's excellent for motion]. There are some excellent fighting scenes nonetheless, probably due to animators great sense of angling and proportions, their clever use of special f/x like slow-motion and blur but also by capturing the right level of fierceness in the characters' faces while in battle. Just their faces and their screams alone kept me riveted to the screen during the fights. 

The art style I really enjoyed, the coloring and shading gave Claymore the overall appearance like you were reading a graphic novel, very dark and gritty. All the towns were modest and medieval looking, the forests were foreboding and the beasts were downright scary.


~audio

I watched this show both in Japanese and English. I'm pretty comfortable with watching it either way...but I do tend to watch dubs because I'm a terribly slow reader and I would be reading the captions the whole time and never once get the chance to fully take in the scenes or see characters' faces. But I did watch Claymore in both formats and I did enjoy the English dub mainly because the language was rough and real, there's no nice, censored fluffy language in this one....yes!!!!  All the voice actors were very serious and intense, the females all sounded like fierce warriors and were to be taken seriously, no one sounded cutesy or “princess-like” in this anime. 

The sound f/x were also great for this series, I liked the sound of of the swords clashing at high speed, the sound of steel grating against the yoma's claws and the whistles of the pyrotechnics and the boom of a building being smashed... I even liked the roars the monsters made. So I would say the audio and visual aspects of the show worked well together to make the show dark and gritty without being too gloomy or depressing. 

The musical choices of the OP and ED could have probably been better. I think that they do match the overall tone of the series but I just wasn't too crazy about them... but the music they use within the episodes are pretty cool like that one freaky,warped sounding song that they play whenever something is about to happen like a battle, that song I love. Every time I hear it I'm like “Oooooh ssssshhhiiiiiitt, something's about to go down.”


~story

A good story is one that gets you hooked, feeling compelled to know what happens next. A good story evokes emotions from the viewer like sadness, anxiety, tension, laughter and all the rest. A good story will even make you forget that it's a story. Claymore is that type of a good story. I think what works for me with Claymore is the equal combination of emotion and action. I really dislike shows that seem to just have a lot of senseless action that leaves you wondering why they're all fighting in the first place...same thing goes for shows with excessive emotional drama [and there were a few points in this show when I wanted to grab that boy, Raki, by his hair and yank him out of the scene with his constant crying and sniveling]. I don't mind people crying and stuff but the constant whining or overly anxious people get on my nerves. Claymore tends to find a nice balance between the two. 

What I also liked about this story format was the use of flashbacks that extended for 3 or more episodes, especially since it gave great insight into Claire's mind and also understanding the importance of Theresa. And since Claymore is a much longer running manga series, the animation company too the practical approach and focused on Claire's story which offered a decent conclusion. Whether or not they decide to continue the story about “The Organization” or the other Claymores isn't that important...because we still had closure for Claire's story.


~characters

This is one of the few anime shows out there that falls into the shonen category considering it's a predominantly female cast. I'm not saying that there aren't shonen anime shows out there that don't sport a majority or all-female cast for example, there's Mai Hime. But even with a show like Mai Hime, you can clearly see that it was made with a cuter, more girlie sense of aesthetic compared to the much gruesome and violent Claymore. Also most noticeably with Claymore is the absence of feminine sexuality. Going back to the Mai Hime example, there were all the requisite breasts jokes/comments, “panty shots” also a swimsuit/beach episode which is pretty common for a shonen anime with female leads but Claymore steered clear from all the anime cliches and kept things as realistic [within the context of this particular story] as possible. Some of the female demons walked around bare-chested and even that didn't seem exploitive, ecchi or hentai-like. 

Claymore has a fairly large cast mainly due to the fact that we see a large number of these “silver-eyed witches” throughout the anime, all varying in skill and rank. But even with all these claymores walking about I found it most commendable and a credit to the character design team because even though all the claymores are tall, thin and beautiful with blond hair and silver eyes, they manage to provide each claymore with their own unique appearance. It's fairly easy to distinguish one claymore from another, some had different bodies while others had differently shaped eyes or hairstyles. And as I say this I find it funny because this show manages to pull off having distinguishable features for a large cast while other anime shows have much smaller casts and their characters all look alike [whether they're related or not]. 

Since the cast was too large it doesn't make sense to speak about all of them on an individual basis here in this review and most likely you will become attached to Claire since she is the central character of this series.....but I also liked Theresa of the Faint Smile very much.


~verdict

This show gets more than a passing grade in my book and I have watched it multiple times. So I highly recommend it for those who enjoy the adult side of anime.

Yare, yare... at the beginning of the story, I was rather excited. Girls fighting monsters, girls fighting evil and stuff (sounds like Blood+). The portrayal of the character is rather mediocre but the earlier plot drove me to the anime.
At the beginning of the plot we are introduced to the protagonist of the story, Clare (Kurea). Then she met a boy named Raki. The relationship is rather ambiguous. Sometimes Clare treats him like a lil brother and onced she kisses him like a lover would do.
The fighting scene is quite remarkable and the portrayel of the antagonists, a group of monster called Youma, is verygrousome. However, in my humble opinion, the characters are way too many considering there are only 26 episodes. So, the development of the main character is not well-presented .

Story - 9.1/10 (A-)
The plot is supremely well made. A female warrior, known to all as a Claymore, fighting the demons "Yoma", who are actually part of the species that they kill. It's a oddly interesting relation. Sure, we've all seen our share of "Female kicking a** and ending up becoming the goddess" animes, but Claymore brings it in. Having to deal with a small companion that you saved from the Yoma, having to deal with the loss of your mentor by solemnly holding her decapitated head. It's just the kind of show that "goes there". Some of the episodes might be too gore-filled, justa heads up.



Animation - 10/10 (A+)

Every scene, every detail has the beautiful animation i've always longed for. The battles are intense and well played out, the heartache drama that follows is also well animated, even the death of Teresa is a scene that'll always pull me in. Claymore,  you deserve a standing ovation. 


Sound - 8.7/10 (B+)

While Claymore has a superb taste of blending it all together, it seems FUNimation (they really need to take out the "FUN".) always has to ruin something they license. Clare's voice in the english dub is good, something i can stand, something i can listen to. Raki sounds like the damzel in distress who always seems like he's gonna get ex'd off the show. I had to include the dub along with the japanese version. Everyone else is borderline. Now go watch the Japanese version, it sounds more intense. I've always been the "sub" kind of person, but a dub can't hurt once in a while. That said, Claymore along with most animes has a fairly decent (occasionally excellent) voice cast. I recommend buying the Intimate Persona CD, with vocals by the cast. Really worth it.


Character - 9.6/10 (A)

Each character is unique to the story, making that more fun to watch. From the child dealing with the death's of his family in front of him, from the misguided Priscilla with a score to settle, from the heroine that is stuck between what's right and wrong and from the mother figure known as Teresa. Really well done.

____________________________________

Enjoyment:  9.8/10 (A)


A solid A for Claymore. As a fan, i always have Claymore somewhere in my heart. A show for the ages, something that can age over time and still feel new. The Claymore experience  was a blast, and every minute felt like a year. Every anime fan, no matter what your preference is, should watch Claymore. Give it a chance, and you'll soon be forking out the DVD money.


Overall Averaged: 9.4/10

I'll keep it short. This series succeeds in being watchable without pushing the boundaries.
Up until 4th episode it seems redundant. With the introduction of Teresa a story base is established and it moves forward with quick slashes. Best thing about Claymore is tightness of the flow. There is no room to catch your breath, every 2 ep.s apart it tunes up a notch till the end. Without the intention to do so, I became addicted and drained it in 3 days.
Each Claymore basically looks the same except the haircut, as the numbers multiplied I had a hard time differentiating between the characters. Same cocky attitude,different techniques, similar motivations.\n\n
It's generic fantasy world and ending wrap up makes it forgettable for me. In order to enjoy the thrill ride I tried not to read too much into it.\n\n
- SPOILER - \n
The explanation about all the Claymore's being female presents an interesting subtext. Triggering of Yoma powers feeds on sexual pleasure, and every male experiment ended up -awakening-. Once men get excited to the limit, it results in a premature ejaculation. Makes sense to me :).

Claymore is a violent, bloody, action filled anime. It is based on an ongoing manga series that is released monthly, and this is a good introduction to the manga series. I personally had to make a couple of attempts to watch this before I was able to really get into it. That being said it is worth watching, though not a priority.
The main character, Clare, is ranked as the "weakest" of the Claymore. This makes the series an "underdog" story in more than one way. The Yoma (demons/monsters they fight in the series) are stronger than the Claymore, but because Claymore are half-human/half-yoma they areable to do battle with the creatures. This story deals heavily with questions about humanity and right and wrong. The main character has a strong background story, and those close to her are heavily influenced by her. The story aside, it is very bloody and violent so it's not for the faint of heart.


This anime didn't sit well with me at first. The panning shots are too fast, and you're not left a lot of time for the emotional connections to develop. This is no fault to the story, this is actually a decent adaption from the manga. However, it really is moving 2.5-3 times faster than the manga series does. They truncate a lot of the dialogue and pan quickly through the emotional scenes. There are plenty of scenes that are done pretty well, but the anime really fluctuates between "fair" and "excellent." This should have been a 40+ episode series if they had done it right. This doesn't kill the anime, but it does cripple it quite a bit. Also, the ending is very different than the part of the manga it's adapted from. They still leave it very open without tying up any of the lose ends because they're still being dealt with in the manga series. In my opinion, it would have been better if they left it exactly the same as the manga series, but it wouldn't have been the happy ending they left it with.


All that being said it's still a good anime. Manga fans should be ok with it (we are used to manga being butchered when going anime), and anime fans should find it worthy of a little praise. I mentioned before that it is a good introduction to the manga series, but if you want to pick up where this left off then you will want to read the overlapping section that the ending changed so you can see what really happened. It's much more dark, and it really is a lot cooler. 


Add this to your list if you get around to it, but definitely check out the manga series.

Going into Claymore, my anime loving friends had all warned me that it would be a tearjerker. "The ending!" They cried with a fiery passion, "O, the ending! It hath plucked at mine heartstrings, it hath sliced at my heart with an oversized sword."
Taking their advice into consideration, I sat down, got my box of tissues ready, and plunged into the final episode. And as the ending music played, I found myself staring at the screen, stunned at how non-emotional it was. As I recall, I even scoffed a few times and smiled a little.
Story: One of the things that pisses me off about thestory is Clare's rank. Clare is the main character, can be insanely strong sometimes, and is the LOWEST RANKED CLAYMORE. It's explained in the story that Clare's powers are inconsistant, so her rank is low, but most of the time she's really strong, especially towards the end. I could understand if she was in the 20's or 30's, but the lowest rank? It makes no sense. Moving on, the story centers on Clare being followed around by Raki, who I'll get to later. Raki is someone who is obviously just a device to insert more variety (because there are only so many ways one can draw a tall blonde girl) and a way to introduce Clare into the story. There are demons in the story, but they're boring and don't really add that much except conflict.

Towards the end I stopped caring about the story entirely and finished it for the sake of finishing it.


Art: At it's best, it was mediocre. At it's worst, it was downright hideous. The battles, which are supposed to be a main point of the series, consist of a shot of a sword moving, then a black screen with lots of diagonal cuts forming, the demon looking confused and frozen for a few seconds, and finally the demon spurting blood from wounds that seem to have a delayed reaction timer in them. When the artists try to draw Clare or anyone in a very beautiful way, it just causes me to hide behind my chair in fear. The facial proportions were terrible, the character designs okay (I give them props for being able to draw one sort of character 47 different ways), the clothing designs very good, and the youma okay.


Sound: It wasn't that memorable. It gets a five. It wasn't offensive to my ears, and it wasn't great.


Characters: Oh boy.

Raki is a useless little boy who has the personality of dead grass. He's on the sidelines, he thinks he can help, but oh wait, he can't, he's grass, and in the end simply gets stepped on by everyone.

Another character in particular annoys the hell out of me. Jeane, a Claymore who comes in later and I can't say much about her for fear of spoilers, is someone who is dedicated to returning a favor Clare did for her. And she does return the favor. Multiple times. Clare even says that it's not necessary for her to go to such lengths for her. Jeane then decides to follow Clare around. I only see "stalker" when I look at Jeane. Not "reliable friend". 

As for the other characters, they were alright. Nothing to write home about.


Enjoyment: Ehhhh. Whatever enjoyment I got out of the first few episodes were vanquished in the last few.


Overall: What else is there to say?


Watch it if you enjoy long, drawn out fights, blonde women, and annoying protagonists.

Now, I have to go return the tissues I bought.

The first half of Claymore was fantastic. But as the series went on it became more and more action oriented. Not that there's anything wrong with that but after a while the fights became repetitive and lacked any real intensity. As the show progress's we are introduced to more and more Claymores and other characters but I only found Clare and Teresa to be interesting. We also never really learn anything about the Organization thats behind the scenes who control the Claymores. I thought that would be an interseting aspect for the show to explore but it never panned out.
I feel I'm being very generouswhen I rate this show an 8 overall. But the first half was so fantastic that I feel it makes up for the weaker second half of the show. Fans seemed to really have wanted a second season but I feel they did everything they needed to do with one full season. A season two would probably have been overkill for a show like this. I believe it said all it needed to say.

Enjoyment: yes. An ending: no, like most of the "short" animes. It offers a great variety of everything you would want in an anime: action, battle scenes, a little bit of romance (not too much) and the idea of the anime is just something that sucked me in into watching half the anime at once. Is it worth watching? I would say yes. Now let me tell you why.
The story is just stunning. The idea, the big picture behind it offers you a world that you discover with the anime piece by piece. The story flows most of the time, of course there are confusingmoments, but it settles in a while. However  the ending...oh the ending. It actually is a decent ending. It gives us some good thoughts about life, the characters that are rather in the front get their piece and the story is about to go on. I would say a nice ending. OF THE SEASON. NOT THE ANIME, OF THE SEASON. It leaves a large hole in the story and the story could have evolved into more episodes then there are now. But up to that point I was on thorns and enjoyed every second I watched the anime. STORY: 9.


The art is enjoyable. You can see that this is not something, that was just thrown together over night. You can see a lot of detail in it, however it is not the best that I have seen. There is a dark aura present the whole time in the anime, that makes it appear sinister, somehow dark, just to boost the thrill of it. ART: 9


Sound is pretty good I must say, some of it could not fit in better then it does now. However some music was just kind of forced in, in my opinion, it didn't fit in at some moments. All around, very unique tracks. SOUND: 8


Every characters is a story on its own and that is what I like about it. Some of them blend together like water and wine and some are just like oil and water, very realistic from my point of view. What bothers me is that some of the characters a left unexplained and mysterious while it seems crucial to know of their whereabouts. However you can not expect this to be a miracle in 26 episodes. What also bothers me is that different characters have the same wounds and home can heal them some just can't. Why? (cricket sounds in the background) Clere improved through the whole anime like A LOT, while Raki, who was a partly (imo) main character, improved like 0 or close to it. He just wines about everything and is of almost no use. It remind me very much of Ganta from Deadman Wonderland, he just lacks the impulsiveness. But what do you know, he manages to somehow save Clare (actually Jean saves her but let's say that without Raki things would not have gone into the right direction) and it turns out that he is sort of useful.

And while we learn a lot about each individual of the "Claymore family" we actually learn nothing very useful of the Organization. We just know that some sinister guys work for it and they boss around the Claymores. Nothing more, nothing less. CHARACTERS: 9


OMG did I enjoy that show. Some of the characters can really grow to your heart but remember the first rune of animes: never get attached. Some episodes end in a way that you just have to keep watching. The twists are spectacular and not everything resolves as expected, just a nice reminder that it's not a fairy tale. ENJOYMENT: 9


To sum up, I recommend Claymore to everyone who wants to watch a new anime, loves battles and is not bothered by too much blood. Yes you can say it is a bloody anime, not overkilling it but it gets pretty rough. If would have rated this anime according to the ending it would have probably be a 7 or so, but the anime wasn't accepted that well in Japan and the company just probably decided that it was enough and decided to put and end to it... Sadness and sorrow I know, but that is how business rolls nowadays. Despite a lot of us want another season, the chances of getting another one is close to zero. I am grateful that they gave us this (close to a) masterpiece, if even a glimpse to the whole story, it was satisfying yet disturbing because of the ending. 

I haven't read the manga yet but the anime really encouraged me to read it.

And guys remember: you can suppress everything if you just try hard enough. In addition with friends around you it can be a lot easier.

A brilliant anime which boasts strong female lead characters, strong music scores, and a very dark storyline.  The struggle that these characters go through, the thin line which separates their human and yoma side is constantly blurred throughout the series. Th struggle to keep their human minds and push back their darker side. A very good anime scoring itself a high 9/10

Its been a long time since I've watched a quality action packed anime.
FYI, I watched the english dub.
The story is amazing. Even though the anime turns around a simple goal: revenge - the story is full and has lot of depth. Female characters look similar to each other, too similar to  be honest, but their characters feel so different yet so alike.
Not only that, but an anime where the most important main leads are female. The male lead is weak and needs protection, and has some important roles but even though he is described as a main character he feels like a supporting characterfor the main female. I'll leave you to watch and decide for yourself, but I felt like he had importance in the first 10 episodes but after that his significance was meh.\n\n
You will be satisfied with the constant limb-tearing, bloody combat. And there is a lot of it. The closest anime I can link this one to is Berserk. And you know what that means, if you watched Berserk. Yup. Demon slaying goodies. Only unlike in Berserk, the main antagonists and protagonists are the same people. I don't want to spoil the story for you, watch it and you'll understand why I said that.\n\n
The art is kind of old, but is really well drawn. The only complaint I might have is the music.\n
You have some triumph music, then irish pipe melodies, then some strange dub-step and Mortal Kombat like music. Idk how to explain it, but the music feels off in many scenes. I feel they could of done a better job there.\n\n
Other than that, this anime is superb.\n
I HIGHLY recommend it to brutal combat seeking fans.

Claymore is an interesting beast.  The story, despite making some admirable shifts, never manages to be anything spectacular.  The writing is smarter than you might expect (This isn't the anime that uses an all-female order of warriors simply as an excuse for fanservice).  The animation is good, but especially towards the end you can kind of feel that their budget was running out both in terms of the writing and the look of the production.
While I was watching Claymore, it was a perfectly serviceable form of entertainment.  I didn't love it: there were parts I admired but there were also partsI really disliked.  On the plus side, those turns in the story I mentioned before.  On the minus side, the male lead caused my friends and I to coin the term the "Raki Line"  The line below which a character is nothing but annoying but above which their contribution is at least enough that while they may still provide annoyance, they have other reasons for being.  Raki, as you might imagine, straddles the line for a lot of his screen time though he gets at least a little bit of character development to ultimately land on the good side.\n\n
All the same, I find myself oddly dissatisfied giving this merely a 7.  Why?  Because while I never felt particularly moved watching it, and while I can see a ton of flaws and very few A-effort moves, it's something I keep coming back to.  Claymore has lingered on my mind long after I finished watching it, to the point where I've seriously been looking into picking up the Manga.  There's something here that has a lot more weight than anything I can technically rate on the scales we're given.  Is it the story?  The art?  The characters?  I didn't enjoy Claymore more than so many other shows that I think about less when I was watching it... but it has some sort of heart or spirit that really shines through, and I can't help but recommend it as something that may very well stick with you in a very good way.

It started at a 7 and had the potential to go like an 8 if something really really cool happened. It was already just cool with the action and cool sword fighting that was going on. In addition to crazy random creature abilities and fighting abilities and stuff. So that part of the show was definitely cool, I enjoyed it.
There were many things to be answered, and many interesting points to be looked at. But none of them were really addressed, all the questions you might have are like, well nope. There were also things that just weren't necessary and/or relevant to the plot theydeveloped. For instance, it is clear within 10 episodes who Final Boss is. However, episodes after it they introduce Final Boss 2, Final Boss 3 and implicitly Final Boss 3,4, and 5. Why they do this? I don't know, it definitely did not need to happen. Was meaningless to the storyline, and gave rise to more questions.


They honestly had a streamlined, clear, concise road ahead of them which was not complicated at all. They however, did not take it. This reaaaaaaallly looks like the kind of thing that has continuing story in the manga, whereas that's it for the anime. There's so many questions and loose ends, I know there has to be more; it really feels like I'm only half way through the story.


The ending song for the anime is awesome. What can I say, I love the ending. It's by awesome cute former bemani group BeForU member, Riyu Kosaka. Who makes awesome group (and individually) makes awesome DDR/Beatmania songs.


Ending was lame I think.


It ends up getting a 5, and I'll tell you why. Simply because of the cool action, sword fighting scenes, and the awesome ending song for the show. The ending song actually prevented it from getting a 4 in my opinion. Nonetheless, with the amount of unanswered questions and disappointment arising from series completion,  it gets lots of minus points. Resulting in a 5. I enjoyed it but there were noticeable issues by the end of the show.

Sharper than Scottish sword and more explosive than Claymore mine! This series and its charming yet deadly protagonist knows what it's doing. Although I would be extra careful with phrases "Don't lose your head", "Give me a hand" and "Are you pulling my leg"... cause it can be taken literally.
I don't know how many swimming pools of ketchup and grape juice would be spent if this was a live action show, but I have a feeling that it would be a lot. Amazingly inaccurate but even more hilarious bloody equivalents of oil well makes you either stare at screen with half smiling opened mouth orjust yell "Yeeeaaah" and enjoy the adrenalin. This show doesn't screw around with its action sequences. Blood, gore and limbs fall as snow on Christmas and shocking scenes of several ends of human anatomy being chopped off sometimes resemble George R. R. Martins sudden twists.


It might seem like an overused formula at the very beginning. Monster hunter meets a boy and they travel together, learning things about themselves and growing closer with every adventure. But it's so much more than that. Episode by episode we learn more about mythology of Claymore world, silver eyed witches, rules that they need to abide, and what happens, when they don't. Claymores has a lot in common with Sapkowskis witchers and little something with Grey Wardens from Dragon Age series. The mythology is beautifully complex.


I started watching it in original Japanese and even though I enjoyed voice of Romi Paku in role of Teresa and got excited by recognizing Narutos voice in one of side characters, I switched to English dubbing. Dramatical acting of American cast is just breathtaking. Soft voices in quiet emotional scenes as well as intense heartbreaking screams of fighters being stripped of their humanity to become an Awakened beings.

Also props to making a lot of characters a lot more than you would expect. It is quite common in anime for even villains to have their reasons why they turned to the dark side. They are not evil, because they want to be. There are traumas and soul-crushing tragedies behind that evil persona.


Even though at times I had to force myself to watch it, I'm glad I had privilege to see and experience Claymore. It is an exceptional anime, with complex characters, hard-core messy infinite-blood-mod action and great emotional character interactions. William Wallace would be proud, Geralt would be jealous... and interested. And viewers satisfied.

clare fate, and lot in life within this  world is a tough one. She walks a very thin line as a silver-eyed slayer. One who is both, yet neither. Of course I want to see where the rest of her story and that of her comrades leads to! this is a great story of revenge , if your looking for something with blood, war revenge, hatred, anger, madness, all that is in this 26 episodes of claymore. it  start off with blood it ended in happiness. this story keeps you on the edge of your seat wanting more. the more you watch themore each of the women tie in together the weird part is they all meet. i don't want be a spoiler but that's all i will say. the characters are amazing there roles was superb. never seen or heard a story like this . this is a story i will recommend to anyone that just getting off into animes.

This was the first anime series I've ever watch, it was on netflix streaming and I had nothing to lose. My only other experiences with anime before was seeing Vampire Hunter D like 14 yrs before of which I barely remembered anything about it.
Anyways, I loved Claymore! The main characters are great, Clare is a great example of a strong feminine type and doesn't use sex as tool. Raki is also a great character who meshes perfectly with Clare's stone faced obliqueness. He brings a lighter and warmhearted side to the show. Personally, the strong quiet main female role that Clare portrays is my favoriteaspect of this series. The story is interesting and not overly complicated. The supporting characters are unique and bring their own flare whenever they show up.


I had one gripe about the show that I no longer hold but since it was my first anime series I was a little bewildered by the amount of gore, but like I said I no longer hold this as a negative or a positive and instead holding it as it is.


One more thing, I wish the series would've kept going and as a warning... If you enjoyed this series be prepared to get cut off at the end of it somewhat. It closes the main story line at the end of the series but it's left of lingering as if they were hoping to continue it, but that must be continued by the manga, of which I never looked into.

Claymore, as a whole, is probably one of my favorite Animes of all time; melancholic, gruesome, and moving. Although the series isn't as fresh in my mind as I want it to be, I can say that I thoroughly enjoyed this anime to the fullest extent. 
The story flowed very nicely throughout, and since I didn't read the manga, I'm not going to complain about how it diverged from the main plot towards the end. It stayed consistent with itself, and every episode was very entertaining. Extended bloody battle scenes, sentimentality, and overcoming obstacles seemed to be the forte within this show. During some episodesI cried, I cheered, and especially, I yelled. I think my favorite part about the story is that it's constantly introducing new aspects that hadn't been heard of before, such as rankings, awakened beings, the black card, the organization, and the abyssal ones. \n
I absolutely adored the artwork in this Anime. Not only was the drawing precise and the technique unique, the character designs were so original and beautiful. The way they distinguished each claymore with a different hairstyle made it all the more enjoyable to view, because each was beautiful in their own way. Also, I've honestly never seen such fantastic designs for any monsters in any anime. The awakened beings, by far, showcased the talent of the creative directors. Specifically in the cave scene, where the one who was (I believe) unnamed, transforms into this elegant, futuristic looking white monster. I loved it.\n
There's not much to say about the sound; it was strong and acted as a good compliment to the rest of the show.\n
This part will probably be rather long. The characters in Claymore were one of the strongest, and weakest, aspects of the show. Some characters I absolutely ADORED- I couldn't wait to see more of them- and then others were unneeded and unintentionally infuriating. For one thing, I absolutely despised Raki. He is possibly the most whiny, annoying, ill-created supporting sidekick in the history of any anime. I hated him from the second he screamed 'CLARE', and the hate grew even more during his and the latter's 'romantic interlude'. Also, Priscilla had the weakest motivation to kill ever. I really, really disliked her. But every other character I pretty much loved. Scene stealers included Galatea, Ophelia, Undine, Llena, Helen, and Teresa; they were among my favorites in a strong cast. Now for the main character: Clare. Clare was sometimes one of my favorites, and also sometimes one of my least favorites. Her cold personality was a strong point in the beginning, but towards the end, her wrath towards Priscilla grew rather annoying. I did enjoy her, though.\n
Overall, as stated in the opening, this was one of my favorite Animes of all time and is a must-see, in my opinion. I found it on Live Play, on Netflix. PLEASE check it out. :)

Thanks to anyone in advance for reading this review. I first was interested in watching Caymore because of an amv. to be fair this where most of the anime that watch come from. When I watched the first episode I laughed at how predictably bad it was. So after a long hiatus I gave it another go. Here are my thoughts
Story: The story is about a claymores who are half yoma, half human warriors that fight yoma. These claymores have large swords which lets other claymores know the rank and name of that calymore. The main plot involves Clare and Raki. Spoiler Warning: Clare's goalto kill a claymore which became awakened and killed Teresa.



There are two parts of this story. The main part involves Clare and Raki. The other part involves Teresa's story.

This story is solid and keeps you going from one even to the next however, there a substance lacking elements. I will not list because of spoilers but when you watch you will know what I mean. This anime was made when the manga was still going, this should indicate to you what the ending is.


Art: Many people compliment the art and say that it is good if not great. I am not a fan of this art style. Especially since it reminds me of the art style used for Bible Black a famous hentai. Which by the way has good animation. Overall it does the job but not my cup of tea.


Sound: The sound in this show is well done. The sounds of blades hitting and cutting the targets is believable. My favorite sounds are when the claymores are using their inner yoma powers. The sound during the transformations are well done. If you are deciding which version dub or subbed. I recommend subbed because the dub is meh. 


Characters: Except for Raki I liked every character in this story especially the claymores. I love how you meet the higher ranked claymores ad everyone is in awe of them. Every clamore in this show was interesting and I cared if they lived or died. I even did not mind the minor characters. You know the people who were in the villages that required the clyamore's assistance. Clare is just awesome, she never gives up and fights for what see believes in.  She has a heart as well, in that she will not kill innocent people even if just a second ago they were an enemy. Clare throughout the show is ranked 47 out of 50 which is bad. Despite this she is very important in every mission that she is in. Plus she saves everyone's hide during the show.


Enjoyment: This show is great to watch. There were moments that made my jaw drop in a good way. The shows keeps you relaxed and comfortable and BAM something crazy happens and you have so many deep emotions going on at once. This one of the many experiences I have had when I watched the show.  The action in this show is great it is does go on for too long. Also i do not feel cheated in that they cut off a fight too early. 


Overall: This is fun show that has a tone of action/ violence. There are many great and  characters that r you can relates to. I would watch this one again. The only thing you should be aware of is Raki and the ending. Other than that give this one a try.

This anime deserves 10/10 rating! Its dark, gritty, gore level (High) and the story is engaging to say the very least! If you have never seen Bezerk its quite similar and by far one of my absolute favorites! Claymore made it to the list very easily after a few episodes! Im not big on female leads usually because its hard to relate or get into the story but with claymore I was content and later on its gets even better not to say too much but the guys get some actions too so the male race isnt completely incompetent in this anime.  I giveit such a high rating mainly due to the fact its so different than all these other animes it doesnt try to be family friendly and be funny or have a bunch of filler comedy that takes away from the story. Its a never ending rollercoaster ride that when it does end you wanna ride it all over again just to re experience it! I cant say it doesnt have its problems like all animes they are only perfect to some peoples eyes.... if you want to watch an anime that doesnt seem like it was made for your children watch claymore! It is  everything you been craving for if you dislike anime where people never die....

The begining is fine, but as the series progresses appear more and more frequently dialogues and monologues redundant and / or unnecessary.
The claymore's have the same personality except for a few. There is an excessive use of stereotypical female warrior that could have been a little less boring with  some psychological nuance of the characters. There is no cohesion between the personalities and some actions. 
At times the sound effects are not consistent with the scenes. There are a few mistakes in the proportion of objects.
It is a very good story carried out in the most poorly way. Totally dissappointing.

I will attempt to be brief in this review and try not to reveal any spoilers.  Claymore follows two lead characters named Raki and Clare, both whom are cast in a medieval era like Europe where dangerous demons named Youma hunt and feed on their natural and mostly helpless prey, humans.  Raki himself is no more then a ordinary young Human boy until one day fate causes his path to cross with Clare, a powerful half human half Youma female warrior who's seemingly soul purpose in life, like many other claymores, is to protect humans and kill the Youma that hunt them.Adventure and much demon slaying ensues while the two not only set out to seek peace of mind in a bleak dark world but to also find the limits of there own humanity.\n\n
  The story starts with potential but never lifts itself higher than that of a generic shounen and the ending is ultimately disappointing leaving many questions un-answered and character development lacking. The artwork however is  good, the animation is smooth and fluid in the fight scenes and the backdrops of the scenery were drawn with care making the world appear a lot more believable.  I liked the idea behind the design of most the characters but do to a weak plot and even weaker ending you never really build a large amount of attachment to any members of the cast as they are simply not flushed out enough.  That being said the story wasn't bad, it just  wasn't good either.  Overall I would give Claymore a 6 out of 10. I enjoyed the action, the setting, and the art style but the story lack of strong character development held this anime back from being  something really memorable.

Well, that will be my first review. 
I guess people rather speak about things they don't like rather than the opposite. Which is why I'm picking by far the worst anime I've watched for my first review.
Let the rant begin. Note that I probably wouldn't be writing this review if Claymore had a score of 5 on MAL, but it's near 8. How can people stomach it - and more so, consider it good - is just beyond me.
Art. It's just horrendous. I know Claymore is an old anime. I know the drawing style changed a lot over the years. But I don't thinkClaymore's art was ever considered at least mediocre. I'm not even going to mention Hiyazaki's movies, since movies are movies, but there are plenty shows from the same period which trump Claymore in the art department. The animations are pain to watch, the whole world is coloured with shades of grey with some red spatters on top, and the characters and backgrounds are just god damned UGLY. It's not like I've ever actively searched for one, but I can't say I've ever seen an anime with art style worse than that of Claymore. 


I'd like to say that sound was the only saving grace of this anime, but I only recall the opening and ending, which were decent, but 2 songs don't make the whole soundtrack. I can't remember any of the themes in the actual show, which means they either didn't exist or were very forgettable. OST probably was just mediocre and not worth the brain power to remember. However, considering how bad the anime generally is, sound is probably the best part of it anyway.


Story and characters. Yeah, this is just Dragon Ball with an almost exclusively female cast. I vaguely noticed the poor attempts at storytelling Claymore was making, but they were immediately trumped by retarded shouting, last second saves and ridiculous LEVEL UP moments that make 90% of the show. It actually starts off decently, the pace is quite nice, and though Raki is extremely annoying since he first appears on screen, it's bearable, though filled with cliches. Unfortunately, the further it goes, the worse it gets. It culminates in the last 6 or so episodes, in which the storytelling simply ceases to exist.  They are just a huge avalanche of shounen bullshit (that is, again, LEVEL UPs, shouting etc.) that only 11 yo kids could find interesting.


There's a total of 2 possible schemes for each episodes. Both start off with Claire getting roflstomped by whatever opponent, some Terese flashbacks, and then either Claire goes Youma mode or she's saved by a stronger Claymore. In my opinion, I would say Claymore is one of the best series ever created. The plot line as many others say is quite cliche with its ideal of revenge however this is made up for its wonderful character development and portrayal of strong women in the anime world which is something that is not only highly refreshing but also hardly seen in the industry where "sex sells" in anime series of hentai, harems and any other horrid story lines that exist for mere fan service purposes. Claymore is well...a little different, in all the best ways.  
Story: 
The story revolves around an organizationthat creates prototype female fighting warriors called "Claymores" (The term given by the village folk who likely notice their choice of weapon and piercing silver eyes resembling their blades). Claymores are humans that are infused with the flesh and blood of demon like creatures known as "Yomas". The problem with this is the ability to lose control and become one of the Yoma's from going over their physical fighting limits in their human forms. When this happens, they are forced to be executed, otherwise they will become one of the flesh eating creatures themselves. The organization also ranks each Claymore in terms of raw and special skill from 1 to 47. In the main story, we follow the under dog, Clare down at rank 47 as she has her mind set to get revenge on an Awakened Being (Someone who was a previous Claymore but lost their humanity to their yoma instincts) who killed the first person in her life that was there to support her as more as a guardian figure before anything else. In both the manga and anime, Clare sets out to hunt down this beast, making new allies along the way that shape her to allow her raw potential to shine. Little does she know, this Awakened being is the strongest Yoma in the series. 


Art: 

I decided to give the art a 7 due to the "culture shock" per say of switching between traditional anime styles today to styles of 2002. The animation is still farily well done for being something created quite some time ago however im sure many viewers can notice the aging process of animation with claymore's art style in comparison to something like Noragami, TG, AoT, etc etc. I would say it could of been executed a little better but then again this was 2002 so I don't really have much complaints for all the other amazing components the series has to offer. 


Sound: 

Again, theres two ways to view this as well. The soundtracks in Claymore are extremely EXTREMELY repetitive however it doesnt leave a bad taste in your mouth. I believe its executed at all the best times for all the right environments. Many people beg to differ however in saying that the soundtrack completely kills the anime series itself. To this I say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder when it comes to OST's. Some people will say it flows well and others will say its annoying or terrible. Really its all up to the individual. 


Character: 

Character development is HUGE in this series, not only for mere physical/combat changes but also emotional or behavioral changes. This is something that I argue to see better in the manga then the anime but then again the anime doesn't flow with the manga so I cant do much justice for it unless people decide to give the manga a try after watching the animated series. The beauty of this series is the amount of dark subjects it hits that impacts every characters life. From sexual abuse to family killings in the characters early days, each one has a reason to change and a reason to rise up and fight past all their traumas of their early lives. They also learn to change from the characters they encounter and questions the good or bad of a person throughout the whole series. Claymores learn to collaborate and bond over their struggles, strengths and weaknesses and discover that power is not dependent on the number of people you have, but instead the quality, potential and raw skill of one's self. It is through this method that they accomplish as much as they can regardless of the ranked number assigned to one's self. 


Enjoyment: 

I give Claymore a 10 for enjoyment because of every refreshing turn I see within the series. For the most part there is little to no humor in the series but instead very valuable life lessons and a story of strength and determination that anything is possible if you fight hard for it. I also can't stress it enough but the outweighed female to male ratio of characters actually makes this series something equally as unique as it is a masterpiece. Their outfits aren't overly sexualized and even in scenes where sexual exposure is prevalent, they dont deal with the matter in any fan service sort of ways. Its dealt with very maturely (likely due to the setting of the scene and that it wasnt for sexual fan service purposes) but in a way where you can connect with the characters and feel something that no other series has ever shown me. As cliche as it may sound, Claymore brings a refreshing new outlook to the "girl power" clique in proving that women can be equally as strong as they are emotional with the ability to overcome the most traumatic and horrific of events through fighting for their lives and to protect their kind along with human beings. 


Overall: 

Claymore beautifully foreshadows the reality that every one of us has a "yoma" sort of side within us. A side that is greedy for money, selfish and pleasure seeking creatures that are determined to go to any extents whether its good or bad for our own self gratification. We live a life where we are forced to make decisions everyday and trust our sheer "good versus bad" ideals to counteract any situation that society throws our way. Putting such things aside, Claymore is a series I highly recommend to anyone so long as they continue with the manga which highlights everything in the anime but so much more, and executed far much better. There is reoccurring soundtracks and a particularly bland plot for revenge scenario but that aside the series brings out so much more then just that and for those reasons I give Claymore a 10.

When the protagonists of the show are female half-demon demon hunters who all wield swords as big as themselves how can it go wrong? Thankfully this show doesn’t try and find out. Obviously enough I find the basic premise of the show appealing and I also find frenetic, bloody, supernatural arse-kicking appealing so this show would have had to work hard to piss me off. That’s not to say that there isn’t some depth here, as the series progresses more and more of the back-story of the world and the characters is filled in and it unveils a deeply layered plotline which underscores and highlightsthe basic (but eminently serviceable) revenge plot that forms the main driving force of the show.


Most of the characters are appealing and their decisions and the fallout from them all add a nice layer of verisimilitude to the story being presented. The actions of the characters and the world itself is presented as a fairly "gritty" and often grimy place and this helps to frame the frequently gory swordplay that forms the main content of most of the shows action sequences.


The twenty-six episodes certainly finish off the main plotline, quite nicely in fact. But lots of plot lines are left open for further explanation and expansion. So I could certainly see room for a second season.

Claymore originally was a manga by Norihiro Yagi and was released as an anime in 2007. It's one of the most well known anime due to its unconventional setting and plot.
Story: 8
 Claymore has quite an interesting and original plot. The story consendrates around Clare a female warrior of a secret organisation that serves the purpose of excincting the Yoma monsters. The atmosphere in the anime is pretty dark, maybe a little gory for some but that is one of the things that adds suspense to the show. For the first third of the show the viewer is getting used to the settings, theprotagonist's psychosynthesis and backstory, when in the second part more attention is given to the present events. The third part is the black spot of the anime for various reasons. Whereas for the rest of the show manga's guidlines were followed more or less the final episodes took a completely different and ridiculus for me turn. Everything was rushed up and the ending was pretty tucky, although the directors had made these changes with a second season in mind which i can't really underestand how would be possible since with Priscilla's death the manga could be hardly followed. If only they didn't rush to an ending the anime would be so much better.


Art: 8


 Claymore's art is quite characteristic. The muddy color palette, the slender characters with the sharp yet melancholic look etc. They did a pretty good job in terms of animation, although i think they overdid it a bit with the "scenes replay" likewise Teresa's beheading etc. Again the third and last part from the battle in the north to the volcano battle was kinda tacky and poor again, but overall the art matched the plot and the atmosphere of the anime very well when it followed manga's character's designs


Sound: 9


 The anime had one of the most beautiful openings and endings in my oppinion. As for the rest of the ost i think it fitted the anime nicely although you could pretty much guess when each soundtrack would appear, for example Teressa's theme appeared when something miraculous happened or when some kind of "savior" appeared.


Character: 8


 The good thing with this anime's characters is that even though their looks might be similar to one another each one was given a distinguish personality . There was a wide range from quiet yet wise and skilled like Irene to cold and sadistic like Ophelia. Also even though all Claymores had gone through the same experince in the organisation it's really remarkable how each one adapted this experience and how it altered each one's character in a different way. The weakest character by some may be Raki since he's a bystander and sometimes a "burden" to the propulsion of the story but in my opinion he's needed because he makes a really nice contrast to the naivity and immaculateness of a young human contrary to an experienced and unmercyfull Claymore. He's also the anchor that many times detered Claire from giving up the battle between her human self and her inner Yoma.


Enjoyment: 7


 It was a really interesting and suspenfull anime with a variety of interesting characters  and a dark and misty atmosphere. However i can't easily overlook the ending part which kinda made all the hard work in the rest of the anime go in vain.


Overall: 8 even though for me would be a 9 since it's one of the most intriguing and suspensefull animes.

I'm not going to write a synopsis, I'll just briefly comment on what it's like so you can decide if you should watch this or not.
So, how can I describe Claymore... it is something like "Cthulhu vs. Girls with huge swords".
As you'll probably have guessed, it's the same as having "Wolves vs. White, fluffy bunnies". I mean, the girls die, and they die so horribly you can't help but wonder what sort of twisted, sadistic mind could ever spawn such a concept and then decide to share it with the rest of us.
There is so much violence! No, really, I just can't express how absurdlyviolent this thing is. A "cruel" kind of violent, I guess. For instance, you spend 5 episodes getting to know a character, her feelings, what she likes for breakfast, etc. and suddenly BOOM! She's dead, just like that.\n\n
Then you go "OMG WTF?!", as though one of your closest friends had been hit by a truck. Then, after the shock, you remember the chances of things ending well were pretty close to zero, anyway. In the last few episodes, the message is something like "abandon all hope" - but when it is finally over, you are left with the feeling that, all in all, it's a pretty good anime, if you can handle the gore.

Mannnnnnn... I LOVE LOVE LOVE super dark, gory, messed up stuff and Claymore is definitely that, so I really, really wanted to like this anime and for the first third or so of it I did. But, ultimately, it's just a pretty damn bad show and has too many flaws and problems to justify its positives.
Art-
The visuals in Claymore are so so I suppose. I'm not sure if this was an artistic choice or merely laziness, but the anime generally lacked color and felt drab and dreary. This may have been intentional, as this is a dark and less than happy show as an ingeneral, but it was meh to look at after a while. The art is not the biggest issue with the show by any means.


Sound-


The sound was pretty bad overall. There were one or two themes I liked and the sound effects were pretty good, but that's where the positives end. One of the important characters has some of the absolute worst and most obnoxious voice acting I've ever seen in any anime and even reliable veterans like Brina Palencia, Caitlin Glass and Monica Rial could not save it because the writing, discussed in a later section, was abhorrent. The problem, even for these very talented and accomplished voice actresses, wasn't how the lines were delivered- it's that the lines themselves were so unbelievably cheesy and bad that NO ONE could have made them not stupid.


Character-


The characters in this show are all complete idiots. Every single enemy in the show after the first few episodes does the least logical, dumbest possible thing in their situation. COUNTLESS TIMES enemies have the good guys in a position where they could kill them and end the fight but they stop, chit chat, hesitate, chit chat some more and basically intentionally wait for the good guys to recover and kill them. Likewise, later in the anime there is a scene where the good guys are in a battle against a mini army and the good guys are already losing. So what does the super powerful general of that army do? DISMISSES THE ENTIRE ARMY AND GOES IN TO FIGHT THE GOOD GUYS BY HIMSELF! If he were to do the blatantly obvious and logical thing- JOIN his army in battle- it's a win for sure and the good guys would be wiped out. But nope... Dismiss my troops who are already winning on their own and go in by myself. And, while I'm at it, same shit as before- I've got them in a position to kill them but instead I'm going to stop, talk, ask questions, compliment them and THEN go in for the killing blow after giving them loads of time to recover or call for backup. This happened over and over and over. None of the enemies in this show actually want to win the fight and they're mind-numbingly stupid. 


All I'll say about the writing, in order to save you guys from another wall of text rant, is if you paid a third grade student to write the lines in the combat scenes this is what you'd get. I want you guys to take a moment to grunt/groan the word "PRISCILLA" in the most fake angry, drawn out, exaggerated tone possible. Also try gems like "I'll kill you!" and "You will die!".


The story has a cool concept, and I love how dark and gory it is, but it goes super off the rails and gets super convoluted not even half way through and it only gets worse from there. And again, a story is only as good as its characters and the characters and the writing are both atrocious.


Enjoyment-


I swear I wanted to like Claymore. I really, really did. It is so unapologetically dark and gory- think severed heads, characters getting full on impaled in nearly every episode, characters losing limbs, characters being cut open from the back and having gaping holes, etc- and I wish more anime were like that, but the awesomeness of that alone isn't enough to carry a show with a convoluted plot, idiotic characters and abysmal and cheesy writing.


Overall-


If you've read to this point I think you know how I felt about the show...


+Unapologetically dark and gory

+The Claymores themselves are badass and awesome


-DUMBEST. CHARACTERS. EVER.

-Writing that is cheesy at best and downright terrible at worst

-Convoluted plot that goes completely off the rails in the latter half of the show


OBJECTIVE RATING- 3

PERSONAL ENJOYMENT RATING- 4

Claymore is pretty awful and I'm going to use this review to defend that statement.
It's unfortunate that this show was done by Madhouse because I tend to enjoy a lot of Madhouse shows. But I guess not every show a studio creates can be excellent. This happens to be one of the worst I've watched Madhouse pump out.
The aesthetic is completely bland. The story follows Clare, a Claymore. Claymores are 6 foot tall Scandanavian blonde women in this world, apparently. And they wear grey to hammer home the fact that the show is completely stuck in the doldrums. Also, there's a lot of Claymores, andgiven their design it's hard to tell them apart. Madhouse had to run through the entire gamut of hairstyles for women in this show just to differentiate them.


There's no character development in this show. What I learned is that there's 2 leads, Clare and Raki. They're listed as "mains." This is a revenge based narrative where the female lead Claire is going after someone, but there's no time for development at all. Clare develops via various deus ex machinas throughout the series as a typical "power-up" for no real reason or effort put into it. She gets the power-ups on demand most of the time. This is why there's a real lack of empathy for Clare in this series. It's hard to be motivated to root for someone when they're continually fighting enemies that at first seem to be hopeless no-win scenarios just to have the hero triumph cuz of plot armor. Let's speak about Raki. He's useless. He doesn't do anything except follow Clare. If Clare is written in the active voice, then Raki would definitely have been written entirely in the passive voice. However, Claymore lacks any real depth to use any literary devices.


The monsters that the Claymores battle are also unimaginative generic copy pasta garbage.


The sound is pretty unremarkable as well. There's some Scottish bagpipes played in the earlier episodes for some unknown reason. I'm not sure how there's a link between bagpipe playing and this world other than the reason it bears the name Claymore. I guess because all the girls wield the same giant phallic worshipping swords. The tracks do switch to some heavy metal tunes later on around episode 20, but it's a little too late. the heavy metal fits the show more, but it's more of a shrug when it comes in.


And the battles in Claymore are simply awful. They're the worst parts of Dragonball Z, the repeated frames. In Claymore, however, it's even worse as most characters bodies are completely stationary except for a flurry of incomprehensible garbage that's repeated over and over as she flails her sword about repeatedly.


Stay away from Claymore. Maybe the manga is better, I don't know, but this adaptation is just soul-crushing.

Coming halfway through the Manga’s 13 year run, Claymore is at its core a revenge tale full of action and sword play with medieval aesthetics, i.e. the name of the anime, a reference to the medieval sword. 
Over the course of 26 episodes, we get a well paced narrative that somewhat ends with a bang and then fizzles, with lots of backstory, self discovery, and conspiracy along the way. 
The art is clean enough and typical of the time. It makes the somber setting believable and adds to the overall dark tone of the show. The colors are subdued, there is lots of blood sprayingand dismembering happening in the show as well. It isn’t spectacular, but it is entertaining enough. The animation is efficient and really plays well in amplifying the fight scenes. They are dynamic and pretty smooth as each action passes into the next. The high energy is put on full display and it is represented well. 


There isn’t much to be said of the music overall, but it is fitting and a little creepy at points. The soundtrack isn’t that diverse but the music only comes in when necessary and it works to the advantage of the anime. 


As far as the characters are concerned, we follow Clare, but we do get to meet many more other Claymores. There is even a point in the show where 20 or so team up to take on a large group of powerful youma. We get a little background on some of the other Claymores, but that is about it. The anime never dives deep into the most of the characters so it’s easy to keep track of them all. 


Overall, the anime was enjoyable to watch. Rooting for Clare as she journeys along, sitting in high anticipation to see what the next foe will bring, it’s engaging enough that the 26 episodes come and go like the wind. There aren’t too many moving parts, and the anime has sort of a one track that we follow to the end. It’s clear, concise, and gives just enough to stay on track. The plot does begin to fall apart towards the end, as it throws us into new territory with very little setup. It takes a hard left and I find myself wondering how we got to a point where there is an army of claymores fighting an army of youma, and  I will say that the ending was rather lackluster. Claymore ends in an anticlimactic fight that has no clear victor, and yet it was kind of a satisfying moment? The ending felt strange in part to being released when only half of the manga had been published. It feels like there should be a second season or something more to cap off the anime, but what they have given is more than sufficient. 


An intriguing display with a mix between stereotypical anime elements and new ideas thrown in, Claymore is an anime fit for anyone looking for something a little darker and more mature than the bulk available for view. It is also a good choice for anyone looking for something that was released prior to the 2010′s.

First of all, let me state that I absolutely love the original manga Claymore written by Norihiro Yagi. In my opinion, it's one of the best and most drilling shonen manga of our generation, with great, deep characters, a fantastic story with good twists and so on. Well, several years ago, it was decided to make an anime out of it, when 'Claymore' wasn't finished yet. Did it pay off? Hell no, it didn't. 
'Claymore' is, and let me underline this twice, one of the worst manga-adaptions I've ever seen, an abominable example of what can go wrong if an adaption doesn't stick to theoriginal or does focus on the wrong points. 



Story


The Anime follows the path of the manga for a while, until it breaks on a certain point and goes for his alternative ending. The Problem is, the Story of the anime lacks impact. It doesn't manage to hit the viewer in certain scenes (Theresa, North, Riful, ...) like the manga did, instead the narration mostly feels like mediocre-fantasy. Scenes get rushed more than in the manga and some characters are even pictured differently, if not entirely weaker. And eventuelly, there are the last episodes who are all fanfiction. They're so bad and repetitive written I really got angry how terrible the sourcematerial was burned. In two or three episodes you basically get the same scene four or five times, containing the same message, a girl crying for her family for example. Also, the plot goes in circles for the last episodes, as the writters clearly didn't know how to let things end. What you get on the final is an expectable Fantasy-climax who makes no sense in the context of the original and who abandons several side-plots and important characters (Riful?). Let's just never mention them again. And of course you get lots of melodrama. The Claymore-Anime-Ending is surely one of the worst you'll see in this genre, especially if comparised to the manga. 


Characters


Llike the manga-versions, only more shallow, stupid and annoying, clares personality changed quite a bit, especially to the ending, and while awesome characters from the original at least appear (some of the great four) they quickly disappear and have no valuable point in the narration of the anime. Overall, I didn't really feel with the anime-claymores, and I would descripe them as a weaker version of their originals. And dont let me start about Raki. His character got shredded completely. 


Art


While the manga-art is a bit strange at first, it gets better and better as the story goes on to the point where its unique and iconic. Unfortunately, the anime skipped that development and sticked to the strange-part. Unfortunately the second, they didn't adapt the original-art, but tried to make a style who resembles him in his strangeness but ultimately, comes out as ugly. This is just my opinion, but the art of claymore is ugly and cheap. The characters models, especially in the later parts of the story, are by far more elaborated and nicer-to-look, while the anime seems to have a kit for shallow Claymore-characters with funny-blonde hair. The awalened beaings mostly look cheapy-monstrous and are shitty colorized, the eyes dont have the sharpeness of the manga. And the mouths... aren't well-drawn at all. 


Sound


The Soundtrack tries to be all-medieval over the times. Sometimes, it manages, most of the time it doesn't. I really think Claymore would have deserved a better soundtrack. It's such an epic story with lots of fantasy, perfectly fitting for great choirs and quick action-beats, but all you get are exchangeable low-fantasy-beats you would heard in every other anime too. The OP and ED are of course exchangeable too, nothing memorable that sticks in your head more then five minutes. 


Overall 


here's my honest and safe suggestion: Read the manga. It does everything better than the anime, and I mean everything. While the anime-story goes completely down at the end, the manga only starts, the characters aren't well-pictured at all and overall, the anime just feels like a experience worse than the original, forced low-fantasy where thrilling fights should take place. I cant recommend Claymore to anyone, not the anime. There wont ever be a continuation, of course, thanks to the ending. Fortunately.
